I’m pleased to announce the winners and runners-up for the 2024 Puzzle of the Year Awards (a/k/a the Griddies):

Best Early Week Puzzle: Winner June 10 (Kareem Ayas), Runner-Up May 13 (Jeremy Newton)

Best Thursday Puzzle: Winner June 27 (Paolo Pasco and Sarah Sinclair); Runner-Up May 23 (Adam Wagner)

Best Themeless Puzzle: Winner December 21 (Barbara Lin and Lewis Rothlein); Runner-Up August 2 (Kate Chin Park)

Best Sunday Puzzle: Winner December 15 “Art Heist” (David Kwong); Runner-Up December 1 “Drive Around the Block” (John Lieb); Almost Runner-Up July 28 “The Big 5-0” (Paolo Pasco)

Congratulations to all the winners and almost-winners (especially Wordplay’s own Lewis Rothlein)!

Thanks to John Ezra and Cat Lady Margaret for their help in the balloting process. And thanks to everyone who voted.

Instead of repeating the ballot’s descriptions of the winning puzzles, I’ll borrow the words of the wonderful Wordplay columnists (which, due to space limitations, will appear as replies to this comment).
Sounds great, but this is not the puzzle in the Sunday magazine section which also happens to be great.
I got the "Congratulations!" message before being able to enter 53 Down's whole answer, so my completed grid is incorrect. Maybe another one of those seemingly Android-related glitches?

Terrific wordplay!  
And despite the constructor's resume, no math!

Thank you, Derrick.
Oof, 50 minutes and still had three mistakes at the end. Even after check puzzle still needed multiple guesses to get AGIO/DOGES
22 across has a spelling error. Missing a letter.

Wow, what a S/Funday!

Crossword Revolution D12:  SIESTA/FIESTA

Because we need to continue to sleep and have fun if we want this revolution to have staying power.  

A Crosswords Saved the Day production.  No ™ anymore.

I was stressing on this one. I’ve been trying to finish a weekly set in under 90 minutes, and I’m not like a competition-level solver so it takes a very specific set of Crosswords for me to hit that mark (in other words, a gentle Thursday and easy Friday/Saturdays). I thought working through all the rebuses was going to blow it for me. But I made it with a little over two minutes to spare.

Other than the struggle with the rebus mechanism, this was a great Crossword.
Seriously?  DOGES?  Promise/Keeper?  Like really?

Wow, I thought this was a brilliant puzzle and that was before I realized the 26 letters constituted a pangram. That takes it to a whole other level of awesomeness!

I really had to work at figuring out exactly where and how to double up letters, and that’s my favorite kind of challenge. So much fun!

I wasn’t sure whether or not to enter slashes in the rebus squares, because both letters are required in one direction but either letter in the other direction. I decided not to enter slashes, which was accepted for the solve, but slashes were entered after the music played. 

I hope the puzzle doesn't get TROLLED, because I loved it. 

Thanks, Derrick. Excellent job! 

P.S. Fabulous clue for NONE OF “Your business start-up?”
Fun.

Was able to clear most of this without help but the top-middle portion slayed me -- a stack of 4 unfamiliar terms (MRSDASH, PDQ BACH, ROUGHAGE, AGIO) crossing an equally unknown term in DOGES and clues unguessable without crosses in MRMAGOO, ARCH, SHADE. I'd also never heard of YOUNG TURKS, so that entire area was a bit of a mess.

Theme answers were fun, and as someone who grew up in the 80s, GITANOS shook loose some long buried memories! The days of high-waisted jeans...

Regarding STAGE NAME for “Denver”, Jim Horne at xwordinfo explains that the popular singer Henry John Deutschendorf Jr. performed under the STAGE NAME John Denver. 

I love that “Colorado” is the other half of that clue …. 

Rocky Mountain High Colorado.
Booo two thumbs down

I do the puzzle on my computer. When you have squares with 2 or more letters in them I can't fill in the correct response. If you could give a heads up before I begin, I would know not to bother or print it out if available.

I can see it’s brilliant, but I’m giving up about halfway through, which rarely happens. I would need way too many lookups. Maybe it’s just my mood today. Looks like I’m very much in the minority. Ah well.

This is one of the most wonderful puzzles I’ve ever completed. I caught onto the idea very early, with the fictional composer crossing Fast/car and then protective outfits crossing Wild/bunch. It was great fun to find the other combinations, and on top of that there were so many entertaining entries. 

I got stuck for a while in the NW. I just don’t know many names from popular culture, and I thought dip might be SkIM. But it was a fun fun fun puzzle.

Overall positive - I came here looking for a connection between the 2-letter combos. QB had me wondering if this was a week early for a football theme, but of course not - that it’s A-Z is just fun. 

The only thing that bothers me:
70A & 45D were among my last answers I entered, as I don’t see how the side-grab of an N in NONEOF to make ROADNOISE fits with the theme. 
Am I missing something?

I was surprised to get the music, as I had only J in the JOKER/JPEG place… but boy have I set a bar for unaided solving this week —one I’ll be unlikely to approach again. 

I got the trick early, and had great fun letting my mind juggle possible answers with this added dimension. 

A tip that worked for me: when I decided there must be a rebus, I skipped down in the puzzle, and worked out what was going on over USFLAG. Hat tip to “Mean Old Lady” who often starts on the bottom.

Having just explained DOGE to my mother, who asked me if I was referring to the Venetian DOGES, I found that entry particularly timely and a wee bit snarky. 
Gotta get our kicks somewhere, I suppose.

Am I the only one who picked up the error with the Roman numerals question? To make the answer correct it needs a C between the D & V, as 3605 should be MMMDCV.
The answer in the grid is MMMDV, which is 3505.

Ok puzzle, some of it cute. A little hard to figure out where the double letter went and which way. 

Could someone help with 45 down, roadoise? It is not a double letter entry?
So much fun! Thank you, Mr. Niederman!

Caitlin doesn't link to the how to enter a rebus the way Deb does. Which is confusing a number of people not familiar with how to do it. And why some rebus squares accepy single letters, instead of double letters. Here's the link. https://nytimes.com/2023/12/08/crosswords/rebus-crossword-puzzle.html Hopefully, someone will be along to explain much better than I can.
Fun puzzle. The "perfect pangram" is truly amazing. I am in awe of the skill needed to make this puzzle. No sketchy crosses either! Bravo to the constructor. Solving this was time well spent.
Satisfying but extremely difficult and slow.

That was quite the bowl of granola.  METROD/NOME brought me some fond memories spanning 30 years of my life.  The USBank stadium is amazing, but the Dome was unique.  At the end of every game the pressure to the outside always felt like the building was trying to spit out its occupants.
A little clunky to solve online, better suited for old school pen to paper.

Clever puzzle, but this is Exhibit A why I don't care for rebuses. I'm getting up in age, have cataracts, solve online, and I routinely have to double check all my answers to make sure the slashes are in the right place, and since you can't really size up the puzzle to make that easier (on my browser, the clues enlarge to a size greater than the puzzle), it adds up being a pain in the maguffies. Still, a fun solve -- I don't want to be a complete Negative Nancy.
Really liked it and managed to solve well ahead of my usual Sunday time.
Pretty amazing puzzle, theme-wise.  Took significantly longer than average, but I enjoyed the challenge.  Had to run the alphabet on the 20A/10D cross to get the gold star.

Sunday's triskaidekaphilic puzzle puts me in mind of the chorus of an Elvis Costello tune 

" Thirteen steps lead down
Thirteen steps lead down
There's commoners and kings
And everyone's a prisoner of
Paper and glue and a decent pair of scissors
So tonight I'm drinking to your health
Because I just can't stand myself
Thirteen steps lead down
Thirteen steps lead down"

Congrats to our puzzle kings who conquered this one -- I'm drinking to your health. And no worries, I'm sitting, not standing.
I eventually got all the rebuses except it accepted the non rebus answer trex for 116A? Was this an exception to these doubles requiring a rebus?

Loved it, super clever! Got tied up on 35D for a while, thinking it was SCARLE T/A but finally figured it out. My only teeny complaint is that HOLLAND is a noun and DUTCH is an adjective. I wanted the parts of speech to match, but it didn't interfere with the solve. Also, I still don't understand NONE OF for 70A? Haven't looked through all the comments. Anyone?
I solved it in a little less than an hour, so I guess that l shouldn't complain, but a Sunday rebus is just so tedious to me. They used to be a relaxing fun solve. A rebus is very seldom fun.
This one took me forever but I loved it.
Devious, took me forever to figure out the theme, a slog for me
Great puzzle! Hard but satisfying.

This is no disrespect to Joel, but has anyone else noticed a nice uptick in quality since Will Shortz came back? The puzzles are more challenging in a fun way. 

Again, Joel did a good job but nice to have the goat back.
Rachel weisz
A clever puzzle, but too much work.  I gave up eventually.

Yup, there's the Saturday puzzle/epic struggle that I was looking for! In fact, this Saturday was *so* deviously sneaky that it showed up on *Sunday* (and for extra camouflage, packed on some extra squares). Nice job, Derrick, and, no, I don't need, nor want, those two hours (!) back 😀

Strands thread.  Perform no spoilers until after the View All Replies button:


Strands #336
“Album of the year”
🟡🔵🔵🔵
🔵🔵🔵🔵

The spanner may as well have been in neon.

I dropped by expecting to see people griping about this puzzle being unrewarding and a slog, but not very difficult (as I did). Instead, I see that most people really enjoyed it, but thought it was quite tricky for one reason or another. The ten or so extra minutes it took me to solve were mostly spent fiddling with the rebus button. I'm glad for the comments because I totally missed that the rebus squares contained an alphabet pangram. Very clever!

Great puzzle and impressive construction. 
Minor quibble - “Volt” is a unit of electric potential, not power.

Bollocks to Rebuses.

Doubly so if they break the central idea of crosswords. If you get to insist on different letters across vs down, you’re playing tennis without the net.
Clever theme but waaaaayyy too many archaic answers that just felt like a stretch!

Whoa. I was initially a bit irritated at the awkward abbreviations, but I can't stay mad at this puzzle... what a spectacular feat of construction! I can't say I necessarily *enjoyed* solving it more than other Sunday puzzles but it has a definite "wow" factor that makes it memorable for sure. Kudos and all that.
So, I'm dying of curiosity - what was the brainstorm from Joel that finally enabled the pangram? I'm guessing it was the X/K?
This was an absolute marvel, the greatest puzzle I’ve ever encountered. Bravo!
This was fun - not super hard, but definitely took a looong time to finish.   Enjoyed solving the clues (once I caught on).     Thanks!!
@Editor Theres an error in 30-A — MMMDV is 3505, not 3605

I'm trying to solve the puzzle but the amount of proper nouns and trivia clues is just mind boggling. As I'm doing my across and down passes, I run into whole sequences of names, abbreviations, etc. This is beyond unenjoyable 😢

I have an idea! Why not make a puzzle that would consist *only* of proper nouns?

This was a trip! Complicated, intriguing, challenging, exasperating at times, but definitely doable. Had to take a break or two to let things settle, but when I came back to the puzzle I always made progress.

Very clever construction, and I can imagine why it took so long to get it done. Impressed by the pangram with just the rebus letters!

Thanks for the exercise, Derrick!

Am I the only one bothered by 48A, [Holland/tunnel]? DITCH and Tunnel are not the same things.  A DITCH is open above, while a tunnel has a roof.  It's brilliant wordplay, except that...it's not correct.  

Other than that, I loved the theme!

Sometimes it's clear when a puzzle is designed for the author over the audience. The word pretentious comes to mind. 

In the "How to Solve the NYT Crosswords" article it says that only the clues are harder throughout the week, not the answers. That's definitely misleading for puzzles like this. Although I like the theme, I find too many answers obnoxiously esoteric. For instance, I've never heard of the Young Turk Revolution, Gintano jeans, a Jaguar XKES, the words longo and pate, or of PDQ Bach. Sure, now I have, that's true. And while I love learning from the puzzles, I can only stand so much at once. It makes sense that a puzzle like this level of trickery would have to rely on uncommon answers, but the dedication to fitting in the pangram certainly rendered it an overall unenjoyable process.
um what is with 13 down ?  why is it hazatsits ??? thats not even a word man

Wow! This was a really amazing piece of construction. Getting all those two letter rebuses to work in two different ways in the across and down answers is just incredible. Oh, and of course a tough workout for me and did have to cheat a bit in places, but just a really enjoyable challenge. And.. a quite amazing puzzle find today. 21 letter answer that dawned on me this morning, for no discernible reason, was - APARTRIDGEINAPEARTREE And that was an answer in a Sunday puzzle from December 22, 1974 by Anne Fox with the title: "Holiday gleanings." Three other 21 letter answers in that one: ALITTLECHILDINAMANGER WITHHEALINGINHISWINGS ONEVERCEASETHYSHINING And there were other long theme answers as well. Here's the Xword Info link: https://xwordinfo.com/PS?date=12/22/1974&g=3&d=D I'm done. ...
So many years in development but still two identical answers left (TOAST)...
For the mini note that hospital gloves, for the most part, are not made of latex anymore.

The year is young, but this is definitely on my list for best Sunday.  It was well worth the long wait to get this one to print.  A rebus pangram mashup with common phrases for the dual clues.......  Wow!  ❤️

This Sunday’s puzzle has to rank as one of the most frustrating I’ve tried to solve in YEARS. I just COULD NOT get the hang of the theme entries even though I quickly realized that they all seemed one letter short of what I b wanted to put in the space.

Once I understood the alternate letters, I was expecting I could enter both letters in a space — separated by a slash, just like the words in the clues. No such luck, but it took me awhile to figure out I hadn’t gotten
the answers wrong, I had the right letters, but the app would only accept them if one, the other, or both letters were entered in the space *with no other characters*. The way the clues were structured I b wasn’t expecting that requirement.

Random thoughts 
Very absorbing puzzle to complete.
I caught onto what was going on Pretty D_rn Quick, with Mr. Bach and then the Roman numerals.
Greece, Athens, ATTICA. (Duh.)  I've been to the Temple of Poseidon, but Cape Sounion didn't fit. 
Any puzzle that mentions Maya LIN is okay by me.
Did they save up the rebus puzzles for Will to edit when he got back?
Thanks for the fun, Mr Niederman.
This one felt a little sloppy with two TOAST’s and two RACK(S), among some other awkward fill in my opinion, but I imagine it was difficult to make things work nicely with the theme

Now that the Puzzle of the Year Awards are in, I urge everyone to stay calm if their favorites were not among the winners.  

True, if "Art Heist" hadn't won, I would have spent my day flipping over cars and trashing my town, but that's just me.
MMMDCV = 3605
Sometimes you just have to get through a puzzle and enjoy the hate you have for it once it’s complete.  This is one of those puzzles for me.

Oh, sure.  Anyone can find a pair of words with a one-letter difference, like SLIM/SWIM.  But to find such a pair that can be clued with an in-the-language phrase like “Skinny/dip”?  Well, okay, maybe once or twice, but even that, to me, is remarkably difficult.

But then to do it thirteen times?  “Wild/bunch” for ZANY/MANY?  “Card/game” for JOKER/POKER?  And so on down the line?

And then have the one-letter-difference letters form a perfect pangram, each letter used just once?

Are you kidding me?  Who does this?  Derrick does.  He does it in all his puzzles.  He did one Sunday where every symmetrical pair of answers HAD THE SAME CLUE (12/18/16 – find it and look at it!)!  This man is a word quirk genius, a master nerd who creates masterworks.  An amazing talent.

Every theme answer today jaw-dropped me, and that is a solve that I cherish.  This puzzle is easily entering my Best Puzzles of 2025 list.

Derrick, you are amazing.  You are a Crosslandia treasure. Thank you, thank you for illuminating my day with the sheen of brilliance and for highlighting the astounding possibilities that lie in this quirky language of ours!

Decent puzzle as far as these things go. That said, the NYT  puzzle app is continually woefully insufficient for this sort of gimmick. In trying to find the last typo, I genuinely spent 5 minutes trying to re-enter the gimmick clues multiple ways because I had no idea if the gimmick squares only wanted a specific input or not.

Also 48 across had two dodgy clue/answer combos AND a questionable method of input. Surely some kind of record for one clue.

Very clever construction indeed, a masterpiece of wordplay.
As a puzzle I found it a bit of a slog - not exactly one to leave me smiling, but I feel somehow honoured to have completed it! Many thanks as always.

Enjoyed the conceit of this one, and realized I was going to have to think outside the thesaurus for some of the solutions, given how complex the theme was. [Holland/tunnel] to D(U/I)TCH was noticeably awkward, and neither of those could have stood alone, but were clever in context.
Got hung up in two areas JAGUAR XKE was unknown to me---only after the solve did I discover it's just an "E-type Jaguar" in my world.
And BE A DOLL? Thoroughly stuck on that for a long time, hampered by an unknown bun, unknown chart-toppers and an unknown architect in the crosses, as well as an inability to parse that unfamiliar phrase out of the letters I had. Eventually fought through by sticking in some plausible letters and seeing what fell out. 
Does anyone ever say? And do they ever actually get the help they're asking for if they do? It makes me tense just reading it, let alone uttering it.

Sat back after the happy tune and decided I was so impressed by the number of themed rebus pairs that I'd count them, out of curiousity. Thirteen. Wait a minute ... And actually said "You're kidding me!" aloud in an empty room when the pangram dropped.

An altogether different experience for me from the drudgery experienced during  the equally clever "Art Heist". Very much enjoyed this one.

Brilliant and challenging Sunday!
Caught on to the theme early with Q/BUIK AND HAZMATSUIT (though it took awhile for the rebus placement on the latter to be clear.) 
I was rewarded for being patient and letting this unfold over a few sittings. All of the unknowns were revealed through the crosses. 
Thank you @Derrick Niederman!

This rebus laden puzzle was a delight from start to finish for me.  And what a feat of wordsmithing it was.  I was happy to see PDQ/BACH get a moment in the spotlight, although it saddens me that so many seem to be unfamiliar with his work.  Peter Shickele’s classical music satires were part of the comedic landscape of my youth, along with Tom Lehrer, who also appeared in the puzzle recently.  Shickele was also a serious musician, composing, among other things, music for the movie Silent Running, and gorgeous orchestrations for Joan Baez’s albums, Noel and Joan

The big question for the Mexican groundhog today:  SIESTA o FIESTA?

And what will the French groundhog see?  Her chateaux?

Does anyone know any other groundhog jokes?  Because I keeping hearing the same ones over and over again.

Just wanted to thank folks for their kind comments and to address a couple of questions that I saw in the queue:

Someone asked about Joel's eleventh-hour edit, and the answer is that he removed ROUGH/ROUGE (Abrasive powder) from the bottom left and relocated the H/E pairing (to PATH/PATE -- Trail/head). Why? Because he was concerned that (Carol) Heiss, the figure skater who defined the crossing entry, might not be sufficiently well-known nowadays.

As to the nitpicks vis-a-vis DUTCH/DITCH, they are absolutely right: It's syntactically awkward. Yet I found it irresistible, especially given that it doubled-up the upper right corner. (Whose other entry was originally ZANE/MANE, as in Grey hair, as opposed to ZANY/MANY.) And COLT/VOLT is indeed a slight abuse of "power," but this puzzle required some artistic license.

The TOAST repetition didn't faze me at all, given that the word is only part of the answer and it's being used differently, but the RACKS dupe was indeed real. CD RACKS came out of Joel's late effort, as WINE RACK already existed in the NE corner. I suggested replacing it with WIN A RACE, but CARED then would become CAR AD and we had a few cars already, including within a theme clue.

Finally, my original puzzle had thirteen slashes (unworkable online), which was a faint clue of the pangram -- which I in turn hoped would be a genuine solver's aid as they progressed through the puzzle (what letters haven't appeared yet). Oh, well. Thanks again to all.

Despite the need for a lookup in order to penetrate that top middle section, I thoroughly enjoyed this puzzle. A lot of back-and-forth incremental progress was involved, which may seem tedious to some but made the methodical part of my brain happy. 

I was fooled by the Cheers clue (had “Boston” until I realized that “tang” made no sense for 88D), and was led astray by the clue for 126A, as my dog has always been my happiest companion. I also smiled at the wordplay for 70A (“your business start-up?”). That one took me a minute.

Excellent puzzle, and a great start to the day. Thanks, Derrick.

I read the column and was still confused about 70 D (NONEOF). But, in writing to ask for clarification, I got it. Brilliant! I need more coffee. 

TIL AGIO -- a lovely word for a really annoying bank charge. But at least for a while now I can avoid AGIO, as I boycott trips to the US and buying stuff from US stores. Oh no!!! What about my NYT puzzle subscription? Less than 24 hr and I'm already making exceptions.

This puzzle is the crossword equivalent of conceptual art: I can step back and appreciate it as an intellectually impressive construction, but as an actual crossword it was so forced as to be unenjoyable. I solved the puzzle without lookups, but basically did so under protest.

So many problems:
— JAGUAR XKES may be beloved by sports car aficionados, but that’s well outside common knowledge. I deduced it from the crosses but it felt forced.
— MMMDCV wasn’t obscure, but it sure was artificial. The feat of a pangram in the themers looks less impressive when you get the V and X from these sorts of gimmicks. 
— VOLT is not a measure of power. A DITCH is not a tunnel. This isn’t a matter of “a clue is not a definition” — they are simply wrong, justified only by the requirements of the theme.
—“Gummi Bears” is a trademarked name for a particular brand of candy; “gummy bears” is the generic term in wide use. So if the answer is GUMMI then “Bears” needs to be capitalized in the clue. There’s no way around it.
— Understanding 18D, 24A and 77A relied on knowing what movies a B-list actress starred in 15 years ago, being familiar with a 30th-century classical music satire, and knowing that a country singer popular 50 years ago adopted his last name for the stage. 

Again, I managed to solve the puzzle. I know it’s called a “crossword” for a reason. But when 7 of 13 themers rely on esoterica or outright gimmicks, that’s a sign to me that the puzzle is too clever by half.

Ooooh! This was a slog for me. Not because of the theme and clever work with words but everything else!

A seasoning brand, a Missouri quarter, a bunch (forgot it means MANY in US), KIA, a stadium. Mount Rainier, AGIOand so on, and all the proper names apart from OTIS and PRAD A.

I finished through crossers and guessing, going over and over as I got a letter here and these. BUT hooray! My first ever baseball clue solved with HOME RUN!
Hoo-ee...that PDQBACH/DOGES/AGIO nook of the puzzle almost did me in. Cool puzzle!

EXCELLENT puzzle! The best Sunday puzzle I can remember in quite some time. At exactly the right level of difficulty for me. (I didn't think I would be able to finish at more than one point, but then pushed through.) If you read this, Mr. Niederman, thank you!

Whee!!
Yesterday, I was looking for crunch.

Found it!

And it came with
80’s fashion, TINA Turner, GUMMI bears and Cheers!

CC’s wheelhouse, fo sho.

Yesterday, I spent my *entire* Saturday 
constructing. 
No. That’s a lie. 
*Attempting* to construct.

Hours.
And I think all I have to show for it is
3 pages of scribbles, ideas, search results,
and two failed grids.

This one is mind-blowing.
Seriously… 🤯.

POY candidate, obvs.

Happy Sunday all!
I assume others have mentioned this, but the answer to 39 down is NOT a unit of power. The constructor(s) needs to retake Physics 101.

Blimey. That was a workout and a half, in the best possible way. A proper Sunday poser.
It took a little while to work out the rebus element; HAZ/MAT SU/IT was my eventual way in, though it took forever to get some of them; D/NOME, STAG/TE in particular, but what a thrill when I worked each one out (I really should get put more).

Boston before IN A BAR made me chuckle. I also liked the mini car theme as well. An Xtype JAGUAR, as we call them here is my dream car. I got to drive one many years ago, lent by my boss to take my best friend to her wedding. Smooth as silk, gorgeous as an Arab stallion, the bonnet (hood) a mile long in front of me.  I still have the photo of a 25 year old me, looking proud as punch behind the wheel. 

Yes, there were a couple of clunkers (DITCH for tunnel, TOAST twice) but forgivable as the overall theme and grid gave me so much pleasure.
What's with HRNIA?
NONEOF your business made me smile.
This has far too many proper names.

Very clever theme clues but ultimately just tiresome.  Much of the puzzle was pretty easy and the theme clues became annoying more than anything else.

This is another good example of why people hate rebuses here.

But I expect I'm in the minority and/or a bad mood.

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)
The right amount of challenge to keep me going. Well done!

If you're a subscriber and don't care for rebuses, open the answer key and simply fill in the multiple letters per square. Or, if not a subscriber, go to Rex Parker's website and find the rebus fills from there. Once done (and it is tedious) you will be left with a crossword puzzle.

To me, this felt like a perfect puzzle.  It was challenging and layered, with no clues that, as Peter Griffin would put it, "insist upon themselves." It also had the hallmark of the crosswords that first hooked me into solving puzzles back in the late 1980s: respect for the past.  I liked how the puzzles of yesteryear used to make me have to learn about old Hollywood, old language, old sports stars, etc.  They never felt like they catered to me, which made me even more determined to try to solve them.  Waiting until the next day to see what I missed was instructive and also made me feel like I was being woven in to greater culture that was forged before me.  While a young solver would struggle with clues like 75A, 77A, 94A, 123A, and my favorite, 61A (I just last night told my son, while watching old Super Bowl shows that the Vikings have not returned to the Super Bowl since moving into (and now out of) the answer to this clue), they will be learning about various aspects of our culture.  And because I went through those struggles as a Gen Xer, today I was able to answer such clues as 27A, 98A, and 126A, answers that stretch back to well before my time.  Mr. Niederman, much thanks!
This puzzle gets nothing from me. Another case in which I spend more time trying to figure out how to enter the double letter squares than I do solving. I’m about to give up. To hell with it.

This was fun!  It was a kind of near-Schrödinger trick - maybe even better? To find phrases like “card game” that can become “joker/poker”. Once I saw how it worked I enjoyed figuring them out with few, if any, crosses (50% success rate).

Naturally there were a few temporary funny wrong answers:

The start of O Come all Ye Faithful could be a CONGO solo.

Help me out here, because I’M A DORK.
I think it should have been GUMMIE and USFLAG

All of the 'three-way intersections' have me feeling a bit dizzy (or maybe it's my giant cup of coffee--in my "I violate community guidelines" mug--the gift from a 'friend.'.)  

This really was fun, and by the end I was marking the Across/Down lines that would have a split entry along with a Down/Across entry that yielded an inclusive answer using both letters.  That helped speed things up, though I still had to drop the pen so as to pick up my magnifying glass every few minutes.  Work, work, work!

Derrick Niederman  ....um-hmm.  From the Nether World, I gather.
Noticed the OGRE and TROLL that were included.  Just sayin'.
Looking forward to more....sorta.  
You know:  the mixture of Joy/Dread.
Derrick, the constructor, posted a comment .  I think everyone should read it as he gave his take on some of your concerns with this puzzle.
Great puzzle, fun!  As a matter of accuracyI would only comment that a watt is a unit of power. The appropriate clue for 31 down should be horse/potential.
Love a good Sunday rebus puzzle. Cheers! That was fun.

This was really fun.

(But VOLT and DITCH? No way. Editors?)

Between that, Hazmat and 3605, the rebus presence was not too difficult to detect.  Jaguars always bring to mind a jumble of X,J,K,E and S letters for me. Since it came up a few times, I feel like weighing in on the word "volt."

Apparently, it is not a measure of power, but instead potential, if I understand the comments below correctly.

But for an average Joe like me and some of the others here, it is interpreted as a measure of power.

When I buy a battery, the volts are sometimes listed. For example, I have a box of AA batteries that states they are 1.5 volts. And 9 volt batteries are labelled as 9 volts. 

I think the non-engineers in the world interpret that as being power, as it not intuitive to many of us to look at a battery and think about the potential energy it contains. 

By the way, I have heard that if you take a hit of acid out in the desert, you can see the cactuses fly around like birds.  (Just kidding.)

Returning with two quick thoughts:

Derrick (the constructor) used the term “artistic license” in his comment. I think that’s apt. What divides those who loved the puzzle and those of us whose views were more mixed is pretty clearly whether we thought the degree of artistic license taken (VOLT, DITCH, etc) was worth the reward. Clearly reasonable people can disagree on that point. But we all are unanimous (well, except for the truly grumpy ones) in admiring the feat of construction!

Also: while I was not a huge fan of this puzzle (for reasons detailed in my earlier comment), I really enjoyed today’s Variety, aptly titled “Two-for-One Crossword.” Congrats on the very impressive double, Derrick — two for one indeed!

Great puzzle!  Once I read "Today's Theme," which may to purists be cheating, I found this a wonderful challenge (it took me an hour) but of course the pangram aspect went right over my head.  I don't normally like rebus puzzles, but this one is an exception.  Congratulations to the constructor!

The comments about not knowing YOUNG TURK along with recent questions about NONCOM and NCO make me a bit nervous. If   people  in a community as literate as this one don't know a little military history (Attaturk and his  YOUNG TURKS overhauling  Turkey's moribund army and other institutions) and  a little about military staff structure, our countries are in danger of bad defence policies--because we won't be paying attention or won't know enough to judge intelligently.

For a demented moment, I thought a correct format for entering this bidirectional/Schroedinger puzzle would *technically* be something like “LW/(L/W)”, but even I, particular about formatting and completeness, thought that a bit too much (plus I don’t think parentheses have ever been used for grouping in a crossword answer). As usual, I struggled with the formatting (is there a slash or not?) before realizing my mistake lay elsewhere.

As is the case in almost all stunt puzzles, the construction takes a toll on its solvers, this time taxing us with awkward clueing (93A), stretchy wordplay (48A), contrived answers (30A), and pesky naticks (20A/10D), but what a construction it is! Bidirectional and Schroedinger (clued with mostly sensical phrases) answers that use all letters of the alphabet! The ambition is great, and for me, the solve tolerable.

“PEG” as the answer for an image file is dirty pool.  .PEG files are extremely esoteric, to the point that there’s no standardized use of the extension (multiple apps use it for different purposes). The clue wants, in descending order, JPG, PNG, GIF, IMG, or BMP.

The clue for 31 down, which has "VOLT" as the answer to "power," definitely does not meet the standards of the NYT crossword and is in fact borderline offensive. First off "VOLT" is a technical term and as such, the clue should be evaluated in such context. To anyone with a knowledge of physics or engineering this answer is wrong and thus it penalizes those who know what the words really mean. Second, and more importantly, basic reasoning about power and energy is fairly important in today's society. Confusion of units is very common in public discourse leading to many statements regarding power generation and energy consumption that are totally nonsensical. This is not a particularly obscure thing nor is it one where slang or descriptivism much applies. The clue is just a mistake.

May 23: “First, allow me to give kudos to Mr. Wagner for filling this grid. Making a puzzle where the true answers are basically hidden but what we write in the squares are unrelated words or phrases is next-level constructing as far as I’m concerned. Themeless:

December 21: “This is not an easy crossword, but it’s certainly a friendly one. The humor is kindhearted, and the trivia is pleasantly nostalgic. It’s the first collaboration between Barbara Lin and Lewis Rothlein, two terrific constructors. They’re both crafty and clever, and they harmonize beautifully./Many entries in this grid aren’t notably difficult, but their clues have a subtle enough twist to look impermeable — until you tilt your angle of thought just a smidgen. That aspect makes for a winner of a solve for a maximum audience, and it is no small feat.” [Caitlin Lovinger]

August 2: “It has been a while since I’ve written a First Pass Friday, the occasional feature in which I show readers how I forged my way into the dreaded, second-hardest puzzle of the week (the hardest is on Saturday). I had trouble finding a way into Kate Chin Park’s entertaining, formidable puzzle, so I thought that some of you who are just starting to play the crossword might be interested in seeing how even an experienced solver can be tripped up.” [Deb Amlen]

Sunday:

December 15 “Art Heist”: “Solvers, I needed scratch paper and a pen to get through this amazing puzzle — if you’re feeling like your head is a snow globe with the Louvre inside that’s just been shaken, jotting things down will help. There are 20 entries in this theme set, half of which involve a deleted letter string and the appearance of a discordant, unchecked letter from a crossing entry. Those single letters, read from top to bottom, are a punchline for the whole theme./It’s a lot, but it’s fantastic! It took me a lot of circling the grid, and a few missteps, to see the big picture (no pun intended).” [Caitlin Lovinger]

December 1 “Drive Around the Block”: “We are in the arena today! You may notice an island of squares in the center of this grid, a three-by-five rectangle that is disconnected from the rest of the puzzle’s entries. Circling this area are seven theme clues, all indicated by asterisks, . . . . There’s also a revealer entry at 93-Down. . . . Solve 93-Down, the [Machine waiting to enter the middle of this grid, as suggested by the answers to the starred clues], and your solve will move from frigid to red hot. This is a ZAMBONI — which smooths, cleans and glosses over the scratched surface of an ICE rink. (Also, for the purposes of this puzzle, on a “Drive Around the Block” of ICE that forms the grid’s center.)” [Caitlin Lovinger] (Kudos to the NYT tech team for the animated Zamboni that appeared when the puzzle was solved.)

In order to not incur wrath among those who have no idea how to enter multiple letters, the tech team has set it up so that the electronic solve is satisfied a number of ways, one of which is by allowing the first letter of a rebus, and even both first letters if the rebus reads differently in each direction.

Frequent commenter David Connell suggests that if your last blank box is a rebus box, delete one letter somewhere else before you enter the rebus, and then go back and reenter the letter you deleted.

Otherwise, your solution will be registered as complete as soon as you've entered the first letter of the rebus.

This, of course, assumes you care about this, which you apparently do.  Others would shrug and move on.

I am a firm believer of the DC from Weston approach as alluded to by Steve L. As a corollary, for those who ever end up resorting to Autocheck (and I know at least one of the wordplay columnists uses this routinely), when doing a rebus puzzle you can get the final puzzle to have the full rebus entries by using this easy technique. If you inadvertently enter a single letter in the rebus square and it turns blue, don’t despair. Just click on the blue entry, hit rebus, and enter the additional letter(s), and rebus again. If you want to change the order of the rebus letters, instead enter a wrong letter, rebus, and then delete and start over. Obviously this only works if the timer is still going, thus the importance of the DC from Weston trick.

@Steve C 
Yeah, VOLT is a bit of a stretch, but, as you know, the unit for electric current is the ampere or amp, short for coulomb per second.

(joule / coulomb) * (coulomb / second) = joule / second = watt

If you know that the electric current is a certain constant number of amps, then learning the voltage allows you to calculate power readily. There is a direct, commonly applicable relationship between the two, even if they are not actually the same thing.

I don’t think there are any commonly applicable formulas to derive birds from cacti, so that would be a much larger stretch than what we have here.

@Dolly P  The answer to 74A is PAR/Y ... so FLATTERY is the 36D answer.

@Dolly P 

There are 13 2-letter rebuses in this puzzle. If you enter either of the two letters in the rebus square, it's counted as correct, even though you didn't complete the rebus.

To get 74A correct for both meanings, you need to have an R and a Y in the last square, so you get PAR (Average) or PAY (Income), and that makes 36D FLATTERY.

As a bonus, the letters in all the rebuses are unique, which means that all 26 letters of the alphabet are used, and only one time in all of the rebuses.

@Dolly P 

There are 13 2-letter rebuses in this puzzle. If you enter either of the two letters in the rebus square, it's counted as correct, even though you didn't complete the rebus.

To get 74A correct for both meanings, you need to have an R and a Y in the last square, so you get PAR (Average) or PAY (Income), and that makes 36D FLATTERY.

As a bonus, the letters in all the rebuses are unique, which means that all 26 letters of the alphabet are used, and only one time in all of the rebuses.

@Judith Fairview

This is one of my big pet peeves for these types of puzzles — the lack of standardized formatting makes me paranoid when I’m fiddling with naticky squares that I’ve got the formatting wrong.

In the last two months there have been five puzzles with ambiguous formatting. All had bidirectional squares, with two of the puzzles not accepting “Across/Down” formatting with the others accepting it. The inconsistency makes it particularly annoying.

Of course, for today’s puzzle that combines Schroedinger and bidirectional squares, the “Across/Down” formatting isn’t really relevant. But is there a slash or not? There would be for a Schroedinger (in one direction) but not for a traditional rebus (in the other direction).

It would be very clarifying and beneficial if the editors released a “style guide” of formatting for all these types of situations for solvers and publishing.
